Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Amino Acid Infusion in Pediatric Burn Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 10 pediatric burn patients (7.4 ± 3.8 years; 27.4 ± 14.7 kg) and 5 healthy young males (22 ± 3 years; 76 ± 15 kg) as controls were included.

Participants.evidence: The study setting and participant eligibility criteria were not detailed.

Intervention.evidence: Participants underwent an 8-hour stable isotope infusion study, with a 3-hour amino acid solution infusion (10% Travasol).

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the response of leg muscle, whole-body muscle, and non-muscle protein to amino acid signaling in pediatric burn patients 6 months post-injury.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the leg muscle protein synthesis rate, measured during the infusion period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified.

Number_Randomised.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 10 pediatric burn patients (7.4 ± 3.8 years; 27.4 ± 14.7 kg) and 5 healthy young males (22 ± 3 years; 76 ± 15 kg) as controls were included.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Amino acid infusion significantly increased leg muscle protein synthesis in both groups (P < 0.05).
